Before proceeding with RNA extractions, total lipids were extracted from a sample of coconut endosperm to determine the fatty acid composition. The total lipids were analyzed via thin-layer chromatography (TLC) (
Fig. 2 A) using a two phase system, which revealed that the white endosperm layer was composed almost entirely of TAG, hence confirming that the endosperm is a layer of oil deposition ( Oo and Stumpf 1979). The fatty acid composition of the endosperm (
Fig. 2B ) was similar to the expected profile of 85–90% MCFA, determined in previous studies ( Arkcoll 1988, Laureles et�al. 2002, Kumar 2011). The oil content of coconut endosperm was quantified to be 31.41 � 0.13% ( n = 3; data not shown), hence verifying that this stage is representative of both active MCFA accumulation and TAG production, with oil content of mature endosperm reaching almost 65% ( Gunstone et�al. 2007). Following analysis of the coconut endosperm TAG content and composition it was hypothesized that the genes of interest, those involved in the MCFA lipid synthesis pathways, were being highly expressed at this developmental stage as the oil composition reflects active accumulation of MCFAs.
